tweet: Alibaba shares have tumbled 40% from an October 2020 peak. It’s now trading at a big discount to Amazon even though both are growing profit at about the same rate. Alibaba's resilient businesses should help the valuation gap narrow:
Microsoft deal will help Oyo check in like Airbnb, says
New Amazon boss Andy Jassy can’t neglect the huge e-commerce business, but fast-growing cloud services and advertising are also in his cart,  argues.
New Amazon CEO will have cloud and ads in his cart,  says.
Facebook is a one-trick pony that can still kick,  writes.

Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Microsoft hold around $600 billion of cash that investors will be keen to see put to work. Doing deals is a tough sell politically, so buying back more shares could be the logical answer, writes

Federal agencies and states have challenged mighty firms, such as tech giants like Facebook;   and  lay out who can do what and the chance of success when the endgame depends on courts where firms get a sympathetic ear.

When China messes with U.S. companies as in the hack of Microsoft’s email software, the White House has shame, tariffs and sanctions at its disposal. Only the last one might work and it’s the hardest to deploy; companies will pay the price,  says.

Planet Labs’ merger with a blank-check firm values the Google-backed company at $2.8 billion. Making rapidly updated images of Earth searchable may unlock a big market and launch costs are falling, yet rivals are popping up on the radar,  says.

As it merges with a SPAC in a $4.3 billion deal, Nextdoor is not profitable, and its model of a neighborhood social network is easily replicable – by the likes of Facebook. Nextdoor may be living beyond its means,  argues.
Microsoft’s D.C. shield is showing cracks; the $2 trillion software giant’s avoidance of antitrust scrutiny may be coming to an end,  writes.

Watch: Amazon has been destroying millions of unsold items in the UK alone, ITV says. For now the e-commerce giant benefits from a lack of net zero emissions-style global standards on waste, but that could change, says

Amazon has been destroying millions of unsold items in the UK alone, ITV says. For now Amazon is benefitting from a lack of net zero emissions-style global standards on waste. It should be prepared for that to change.
In exchange for ordering autonomous truck-driving units, Amazon can buy up to a fifth of maker Plus. A past agreement shows how expensive the tech giant's validation can be, writes
Apple Daily, a pro-democracy Hong Kong tabloid, could be effectively bankrupted in the name of national security. It's bad news for the entire business community:

Apple, Google have their stores, which are like credit cards, charging fees. But 30% tribute for being listed in an app store environment that is essentially a duopoly is "nuts and will not stand." In future, people won't be paying 30% or even 15%, IAC Chairman Barry Diller says.

Jeff Bezos’s $9 billion potential movie studio bid puts a huge premium on MGM but it could get caught in regulatory purgatory. Amazon would take a coveted asset off the streaming market and a chance to catch up with media rivals,  argues.

More Amazon destruction raises climate-change fears. Former Brazil Finance Minister Joaquim Levy writes in a guest column that animal-tracing tech, integrated farming and better use of pastures may end economically unsound treatment of rainforests.

What do Microsoft, British Airways, Glencore and Shell have in common? They all reckon their greenhouse gas emissions will hit “net zero” by 2050. Though the targets sound the same, investors shouldn’t assume they are, writes

Epic Games has deftly drawn attention to its battle with Apple. But even if the iPhone maker is forced to reckon with how it does business in the App Store, it would do little damage to its $2 trillion market value, says

Amazon’s first-quarter revenue jumped by 44%, rounding out a year of lockdowns and panic buying. With Jeff Bezos on his way out, it will be up to incoming boss Andy Jassy to ensure a smooth shift as a strange but lucrative period ends, writes

Facebook’s ad revenue jumped 46% and monthly active users increased by 15% in the quarter it banned former U.S. President Donald Trump. Other platforms may emerge but established social media can mostly blow them off, writes

Trustbusters in Australia warned on Wednesday that regulation may be needed to address the dominance of Apple’s App Store and Alphabet’s Google Play Store. The mounting scrutiny could prove harder to defend, says  in Capital Calls:

Google and Facebook stand to rake in ad revenue as consumer-facing businesses jostle for Americans’ pent-up savings. The result could be Silicon Valley predators gobbling up an ever-bigger share of the market, says
Alibaba’s $2.8 billion fine from the Chinese antitrust watchdog ought to worry U.S. rival Amazon.  explains.

Microsoft’s $20 billion bet on Nuance is a trifle for the software giant. Nuance’s tech may finally be delivering on its long-held promise, making it an attractive bolt-on for Microsoft’s expanding cloud business, says
U.S. President Joe Biden has proposed allowing other countries to raise more tax from tech giants like Facebook. It’s a concession that could unlock a broader deal on a global minimum levy, says

New rules in India would hurt Amazon and Walmart-owned Flipkart while helping homegrown rivals such as the $180 billion Reliance Industries and the Tata group as they pile into e-commerce. Any benefits might be short-lived, however, explains

Rising long-term interest rates pose a serious threat to investors’ wealth. Their best protection may come not from the likes of Alphabet and Amazon, but from the antithesis to those high-fliers, writes Edward Chancellor:

The FDIC is becoming open to deposit insurance for nonbanks, which paves the way for companies like Amazon. But between access to data and Amazon’s size, it could create more problems than it solves, writes
Microsoft may have to pay up to woo gaming chat service Discord away from going public, writes  on Capital Calls.

Microsoft is in talks to Buy Discord for More Than $10 Billion, Bloomberg reports. In December,  suggested that buying Discord would be a cheaper, and less politically fraught, way for Microsoft to chase new users. Read the view:

Various investors in Polish e-commerce group Allegro are selling down early. But shareholders ought to be more concerned about the company’s poorly received guidance and the spectre of Amazon, writes  in Capital Calls:

South Korea's Coupang might be worth over $50 billion in its New York IPO if valued in line with U.S. peer Amazon, or about one-third of that amount if investors are cautious about growth prospects in its small, mature market, explains

Watch: Microsoft’s possible interest in Pinterest isn’t as odd as it seems. The software giant's interest in buying communities, the scrapbooking site's valuation and its low profile in Washington may all be part of the mix.  explains.

Microsoft made a pass at Pinterest. The potential combination may seem confusing, but CEO Satya Nadella has regularly sought growing networked assets. The $50 billion scrapbooking site might also slip past increasingly vigilant regulators, says

Adyen is one of Europe’s few successful listed fintechs, giving it scarcity appeal. But its reliance on large customers like Facebook could one day become a problem, and a rich $76 billion valuation leaves little room for error, writes

Jeff Ubben may join Exxon Mobil’s board. He helped usher Steve Ballmer out of Microsoft and encouraged an aging Adobe to transform. With vocal and quiet agitators at Exxon, shareholders need a diplomat with experience, says

Despite efforts to pare down and improve disclosure, $12 billion News Corp trades at a curiously deep discount. Online real estate and Dow Jones may be underappreciated. Murdoch’s bad governance and newspaper fetish also get in the way, says

An Indian court blocked Future's asset sale to rival Reliance after Amazon raised objections to the $3.4 billion deal. Re-read  column on how an Amazon victory could cost thousands of jobs, but the standoff also might deliver longer-term rewards:

Jeff Bezos will shed his CEO title to the head of Amazon’s cloud division just as fourth-quarter sales jumped 44%. The new chief will have to address regulatory scrutiny in an era where the $1.7 trillion giant faces a new normal, says

Amazon is trying to stop the sale of a big-box retailer to Mukesh Ambani’s Reliance. An Amazon victory could cost thousands of jobs. The business itself may be less important than the message being sent, says

Apple made $15 billion in revenue from services last quarter. If growth keeps up, subscriptions and such could be more profitable than the iPhone within a few years. It’s also where the company is most vulnerable to antitrust pressure, says

Facebook has had everything thrown at it in the last year, from an ad boycott to antitrust lawsuits. The business still posted a 33% jump in quarterly revenue. The social network's greatest danger may be getting distracted, says

Google threatened to shut down its web search function in Australia if the country enacts a law forcing it to pay media companies for news. Such corporate dominance suggests global regulators may have to put up a united front:

Congress has an opportunity to rethink the 25-year-old law that shields companies like Twitter and Facebook from liability over user content. New rules should also focus on how social media companies amass and use data, says

Shares of Hyundai are up 30% on reports of a tie-up with Apple. Selling software could ramp up margins for carmakers, but joining forces is a shortcut that could prove hazardous down the road, write  and

Facebook bought a customer-relations platform that could be worth more than $1 billion. But the company’s streak of buying startups is ending, says

Facebook and Smith & Wesson have something in common: unusual legal shields that protect them from users’ actions. Without this legislative Kevlar, both would have to rethink their business models, writes

U.S. regulators are reviewing Facebook’s 2012 purchase of Instagram, but unwinding deals is almost impossible. Forcing tech giants to make switching to rivals easier could be a more productive approach, writes
Apple’s $1.9 trillion valuation assumes regulators and rivals will get nowhere, writes

IBM is spinning off its legacy infrastructure services unit to focus on high-margin, fast-growing cloud computing. Still, IBM will struggle to overhaul powerful rivals like Microsoft, says

Amazon has wooed fashion house Oscar de la Renta to its new high-end platform. But big brands may want to wait for peers before taking the plunge. That could mean a slow start, writes
A long who’s who list stand to clean up from Jack Ma’s Ant. Not long ago, a $200 bln IPO might have made public investors look like suckers. This number is less scary thanks to Apple and others, says
The success of Polish online retailer Allegro’s IPO will rest in part on the sturdiness of its anti-Amazon defences, writes

Brands are pulling ad spending from Facebook because of racist content. While companies aren’t wired to drive social change, Zuckerberg’s tech giant may be the exception, writes
Amazon’s new $2 billion climate fund probably won’t change the world, but it’s a worthy sideshow to something that can make a bigger difference, writes

Amazon can wisely flow into Indian rapids, write  and

Apple, Airbus and Asahi are among many companies withdrawing forecasts during the pandemic. It’s a good time to reconsider campaigns to end quarterly profit guidance. Covid-19 should help refocus attention on the longer-term, says

Putting batteries into the haulage fleets of Amazon, UPS and others could speed up the transition to electric vehicles. But much of the work falls on utilities, writes

Facebook is not catching its breath in the race for global domination, and Mark Zuckerberg can afford to ignore risk-averse shareholders, writes

Leaders justify bailouts by saying Covid-19 is “nobody’s fault”. By that logic, giants like Amazon gaining ground as SMEs fall were handed unequal advantages. Tariffs like those imposed on oil drillers after OPEC’s embargo could level the field.

Facebook is paying $5.7 billion to buy a 10% stake in the digital services division of Reliance Industries. WhatsApp will be able to power the retail ambitions of India’s richest man, Mukesh Ambani, and even help build a lucrative super-app, says

Facebook’s chief executive and investors may be at odds when it comes to the company’s cash pile. A dividend would create a tax hit for Mark Zuckerberg, but buying shares would consolidate power.

Google CEO Sundar Pichai will now also lead parent Alphabet. A big reason for the shuffle is elusive, but there may be many small ones, writes

There is an elegant solution to Facebook’s chronic problem with political ads: it could stop running them altogether, write  and

MSCI has said stocks on Shanghai’s recently launched STAR Market could be eligible for index inclusion. That should revive trading volumes, and more good news is coming.
Mark Zuckerberg argues that making tech firms smaller would be counterproductive for preventing election interference, and he’s right. That could be Facebook’s best defense, writes

Watch: Twitter and Facebook have swept Beijing-controlled spam accounts from their systems and Twitter says it will no longer accept advertisements from state-run media. But what media qualifies as state-run?  and  discuss.

Twitter suspended state-backed accounts trying to subvert protests in Hong Kong.  It will also stop accepting ads from government-controlled media. It's an opportunity for Facebook and others to reconsider profiting from propaganda:

The Trump administration has delayed some tariffs on electronics imported from China. But market watchers shouldn’t forget that the U.S.-China trade war will turn on American farmers, not Apple.

Apple is buying the majority of Intel's smartphone modem business for $1 billion. The deal could give Apple a technological edge while avoiding costly royalty payments to Qualcomm,  wrote earlier this week.

Facebook reported $17 billion in quarterly sales just hours after U.S. regulators fined the social media giant $5 billion for mishandling data. More inquiries are looming, but if the firm can maintain growth, it can pay the piper.
